YANG DI-PERTUAN NEGARA'S SPEECH

(Debate on the Address)
(Second Day)


    Order read for resuming adjourned debate on Question [16th July, 1959],

    'That the following Address in reply to the speech of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara be agreed to:-

    "We, the Legislative Assembly of the State of Singapore, express our thanks to the Yang di-Pertuan Negara for the speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the opening of the present session of this Assembly." '-(The Deputy Prime Minister).

    Question again proposed.

2.34 p.m.

    Mr Thio Chan Bee (Tanglin): Mr Speaker, Sir, yesterday when the House adjourned, I was referring to an important factor which could be and should be one of those which would form the basis for the creation of a climate of confidence which the Government proposes to build up. I was referring, Sir, to the Han Raya Haji message of the Hon. the Prime Minister. He said:

    "So long as we remember that all religions preach goodwill and love for one's fellow-men, then with tolerance we can live happily together in peace and prosperity."

    Sir, for this country in particular, we need to remember and not only to remember, but to practise it. The Hon. the Prime Minister once stated that he feared that the greatest danger for this country is from communal hatred. We cannot expect to dispel this fear unless we replace it with something more constructive. I am glad that he had stated these three qualities as being necessary - that we should have goodwill, love and tolerance. I for one, Sir, may disagree with my friends on the Government benches, but it does not mean that because I disagree with them therefore I should entertain any feelings of ill-will towards them.

    Sir, I propose to touch next on economic expansion and refer to the statement which says:

    "It has been their declared policy, clearly enunciated during the election campaign, to give private enterprise, both of local and overseas origin, all the encouragement and assistance they need...".

Column: 157

Sir, this was very encouraging and if the Government will implement this policy, it will help to build up a climate of confidence. But, Sir, as a Member of the Opposition, I have to point out that there are certain statements made and certain indications which make people wonder whether the pendulum is not swinging from the Colonial laissez-faire policy to one of excessive state control and interference. Statements have been made that Government proposes to control all community centres, all boys' clubs and very likely all trade unions. The two do not seem to agree. If we are going to encourage private enterprise in one field, the same principle applies; it means that we have to encourage private enterprise also in the field of social welfare projects. Sir, I put it to the Government that they should reconsider this and if they really want to encourage private enterprise, then they should modify their policy so that where private enterprise has been abused and the people have suffered, then I for one would agree that the State must interfere.

    Sir, the problem of unemployment has been touched upon very briefly in a short paragraph. We would have liked, Sir, for the Ministers representing the Government to elucidate their policy. Then the Opposition could really help to point out where there are points to be reconsidered. But since we do not know what is beyond the speech, Sir, we can only conjecture. The problem of unemployment is very closely connected with the problem of national development. It is stated here:

    "One of the gravest and most pressing problems facing the Government of Singapore today is housing."

    Sir, we wholeheartedly agree. Housing can have a great effect on the unemployment problem. We know that the population increase in Singapore is such that, to cope with just the annual increase, we should build at least 10,000 housing units a year. The Singapore Improvement Trust has been able to build up to a maximum rate of only about 4,000 houses a year. With maybe increased energy and greater expenditure of money the number could be increased. But with

Column: 158

the backlog of the years since 1945 or 1941, with arrears of housing to be made good, we know that private enterprise must be encouraged to step in. Here, Sir, we find that there are two very discouraging features. If an estate developer wants to build 200 houses, he is now called upon to make a deposit for water and light even before he has started building operations for the whole of the 200 houses. Worked out at $1,500 per unit or $1,000 per unit, it comes to $200,000. This means that the developer must first deposit $200,000 with the Government or the City Council. Sir, this discourages the developer naturally. Why should he put in $200,000 even before he starts building, when he feels that the climate is still uncertain? I have a constructive suggestion to make, Sir. That is, if the deposit is reduced and payment made in stages for 20 or 50 houses at a time, that will encourage estate developers to invest their capital. Then again, Sir, this is on behalf of those many workers who want to own small houses of their own. They are scared because there are reports that the assessment will be raised.

    In certain countries, Sir, to stimulate housing, the Government exempted owners of houses or builders of houses from paying assessment for a period of time. Sir, I put forward these suggestions in order that the housing industry might be encouraged to develop further and that unemployment would be helped. At the moment, with the housing industry more or less at a standstill except for those who can afford it, the result is that many masons, carpenters, lorry drivers and so down the line, are unemployed.

    Sir, I come now to a subject in which I am naturally and specially interested. That is education. I have been informed, Sir, that the Education Minister was a teacher before he went into the field of insurance. I take it that with that background he can see a problem from its different angles. I am glad, Sir, that the policy is to accept the recommendations of the All-Party Committee Report on Chinese Education released in 1955. In that Report, Sir, it was stated that a great deal of the educational development in this country had been due to private

Column: 159

enterprise or public spirited merchants and others who had formed committees of management and started their own schools in villages without any encouragement from the then Colonial Government. In the same way, in regard to English education, various missions had established schools whereas the Government was interested in only just a few schools, leaving the main task to private bodies. Sir, we are glad that after the war, the Government decided that it should play a more important part and invest more money on the education of its future citizens. This development has been all to the good. Now that the Government has been taking more and more interest, it is natural, I suppose, that when people pay more money, they want to have more control, because they pay the piper. At the same time, Sir, for the sake of encouraging competition and initiative, we feel that private enterprise must be encouraged and that these Boards of Management which are controlling the Chinese schools should continue with the least possible interference and Boards of Governors be formed for Government as well as aided schools which do not as yet have Boards of Governors whereby there will be maintained the liaison between school and home to which the All-Party Committee Report on Chinese Education has referred.

    Sir, there are two questions at the moment which are in the minds of parents as well as educationists. I remember, Sir, six years ago, because of the problem of limited accommodation, the then Director of Education said that there must be introduced in Singapore the same system of Secondary Entrance Examination as in England. That is known as the Eleven-plus Examination. But he did not recommend the full implementation of what exists in England. He recommended the examination to exclude certain students and not to classify all the students. He said to me that only a quarter at the most of the students in the primary schools should go into the secondary schools. Sir, in England, they have the Eleven-plus Examination as a classifying examination. Those who are

Column: 160

fit for the grammar type of education go into a grammar school; others into technical schools and others again into modern schools. But here at the age of Eleven-plus, Twelve-plus or Thirteen-plus, thousands were dismissed and were told that they could not get into the secondary schools. We educationists believe, Sir, that at the Primary VI level, the boys and girls coming out of the schools - whether English, Chinese, Malay or Tamil vernacular schools - are only half-baked products, and half-baked products can become serious liabilities in the life of the country. One of the reasons why we have so many juvenile delinquents is that these boys and girls come out from the schools without sufficient education to be employed, and so they employ themselves in their own way to the detriment of the interests of the country. Therefore, some of us suggested to the Government that if they wanted to have an elimination examination, it should be at the Form III level, or at the seventh year level, when they would have at least enough education to make use of whatever they had learned to good purpose and be employable. Sir, we were told that it could not be done. The schools were given an ultimatum. Either we toed the line or the grant would be withdrawn. So, Sir, we had to toe the line. Sad to say, thousands of children had to leave school.

    Sir, that was a policy which was short-sighted. The previous Minister for Education realised it too late and tried to reverse the policy. But it was too late, Sir. We tell the truth and we believe, Sir, that the Minister for Education today will not take it amiss just because I am on this side of the House and because in politics sometimes we take the attitude that if that is said by somebody from the other side, it must be bad. We hope that it will not come to that. Whatever is good that comes from the other side, we admit it as good. If there is something we have to criticise, we have to criticise because we are the Opposition. So, Sir, we suggest, if the Minister for Education has not made up his mind yet, that the examination which is now known as the Government Secondary Schools Entrance Examination should be turned into a

Column: 161

classifying examination or, if it must be an elimination examination, then it should be at a level so that our students come out at the age of 14 or Fourteen-plus when it will not be against the Trade Union Ordinance to employ them.

    Sir, there is also the problem of the six-day week. Even before this was introduced, many teachers had been doing a six-day duty freely.

    An hon. Member: More work for less pay!

    Mr Thio Chan Bee: Some of them who teach in Sunday schools have had to do a seven-day week. But let us also look at it from the point of view of the students. When we say that a student does a five-day week, we must not think only of the school hours. A Form V pupil seems to have to do only, say, five hours a day, but he must do homework which entails labour for three or four hours at the minimum. Some of them do five hours' work a day after school hours and, if we take it in that light, a Form V pupil has to put in five hours in the school and four hours at home - nine hours a day. With a five-day week, it works up to 45 hours a week - it already exceeds, I believe, the limit set down by the Trade Union Ordinance. So if we make it a six-day week-

    An hon. Member: Cruelty!

    Mr Thio Chan Bee - well, the children should form a trade union of their own! They could turn to their parents and say, "Look, parents, you come home on Saturday after a 5½ day week. What is the meaning of making us do a six-day week?" So I suggest that, except for special circumstances, the six-day week in interpretation should be a 5½ day week.

    Sir, I come now to the last topic. I wish to touch on Home Affairs. It is stated in the Yang di-Pertuan Negara's Speech:

    "The future of Singapore lies ultimately in re-uniting with the Federation of Malaya as a state in an independent country. It is the Government's intention during its term of office to create and bring about conditions favourable to an early re-unification with the Federation."

Column: 162



    Sir, we on this side of the House wholeheartedly support that objective, but we realise that there are fears, one of which is the fear of the Malays. Sir, we share with them the anxiety and we believe that this anxiety can only be removed if we implement - (I am glad, Sir, that the Hon. the Prime Minister is here) - the basis which he mentioned in his Hari Raya Haji message that with goodwill, love and tolerance, we can bring about a new Malayan nation. We can bring about conditions that will help to link us up with the Federation. Sir, my hope is that this may come about in my lifetime and your lifetime and that there will emerge a Malayan nation when, although multi-lingual, multi-racial, multi-national or multi many other things, we shall be united in one loyalty to this country. We have already an example in the world in the case of Switzerland, and we hope that the national pattern there can be repeated here. Then we shall see in this part of the world Singapore and Malaya becoming one as the Switzerland of Asia.

2.55 p.m.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock (Cairnhill): Mr Speaker, Sir, I listened attentively to the speech of the Hon. Deputy Prime Minister when he moved the motion which is now being debated. He struck a very sober note and showed his keen awareness of the heavy responsibilities that lie in the task ahead. I was ready to applaud and pay tribute to his statesmanlike speech. I was even prepared to overlook the exaggerated claim which he has made for his Party.

    Towards the end of his speech, Sir, however, something crept in which struck a discordant note and this has spoilt the good effect of the earlier part of his speech, and has forced upon me, Sir, to change somewhat the tone of my speech.

    The Prime Minister: You change too easily. That is the trouble.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: On taking office, Sir, the Hon. the Prime Minister issued a call to the nation that in the task ahead each and everyone of us has a part to play and that each and everyone of us should work together in this nation

Column: 163

building. I was indeed stirred by this call and I then called on the Hon. the Prime Minister and offered the Government our co-operation in this nation building. I was stirred because Singapore is ours, ours to cherish and to nurture. And in the Prime Minister's call lies the essence of sinking our differences for the common good.

    I therefore cannot understand why, in the light of that call, the Leader of the House should have felt it necessary to end his fine speech by casting aspersions on the previous government. Such dissipation of his energy, Sir, cannot be said to be contributing to the task ahead. I cannot allow these allegations to pass unchallenged.

    During our period of office, we did all we could within the limitations of the Rendel Constitution for the welfare of the people of Singapore. And even the Deputy Prime Minister did touch on these limitations under the Rendel Constitution. We have improved living conditions; we have provided better social amenities; we have raised the standard of living. We have, and not the P.A.P. as barefacedly claimed by the Hon. the Deputy Prime Minister, led the people towards this new self-governing Constitution. We have introduced multi-lingualism into this Assembly about which the Hon. the Deputy Prime Minister has crowed so much. We have opened the gates of Singapore to more than 300,000 new citizens.

    The Prime Minister: Thinking they would vote for you!

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: We have -

    Mr Speaker: Order.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Sir, I thought a change of place would bring about greater responsibility in the Hon. the Prime Minister. Sir, with the interruptions, what is the use of continuing in this strain? Records will show what we have done. Let the P.A.P. Government chalk up the record of their achievements during their period of stewardship. Time will tell and I sincerely hope, I repeat, I sincerely hope that they will be able to do better under a self-governing

Column: 164

and, of course, a better Constitution. To me the welfare of the people of Singapore is paramount; political leaders and political parties are just in the scheme of things.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: They are not like the Labour Front!

    Mr Speaker: Order-

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: It is all right. I am used to it.

    Mr Speaker: Order. I think this debate is one of quite a serious nature, and perhaps hon. Members ought to remember the Standing Order which does say that when a Member is speaking, there should not be any unseemly interruptions. Perhaps hon. Members on the Government side will allow Members of the Opposition to be heard in silence.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, when the standstill Budget was debated in this House last year, the leader of the P.A.P. did not criticise the budget as was his wont to do in previous years. In fact, he was, to say the least, quietly taking it from the man known as the Member for Changi, who has now retired from this Chamber. Sir, there was no indication from him that the P.A.P. was thinking about pay cuts. Indeed when the P.A.P. Mayor was introducing the City Council Budget, there was no mention made of any pay cuts, and if I remember rightly, there was mention of a surplus. Where then is the justification for pay cuts of City Council employees? And to add to the injustice, these pay cuts were hurriedly and arbitrarily imposed, flagrantly ignoring the accepted principle of negotiation.

    Coming now, Sir, to the pay cuts of Government employees. The P.A.P., as I said earlier, did not give any indication during the Budget debate last year that it would be desirable in the interests of economy to introduce cuts in the variable allowance. Nor did they at any time during their election campaign give such an indication. As soon as they got into the saddle, their economic expert, through some expert computation, declared that there was a threatened deficit of $14 million. Surely, Sir, the economic expert, who has been a civil servant for

Column: 165

many years, knows full well that for the past few years there has been a surplus at the end of each year despite the budgetted deficit.

    I am not challenging the wisdom of the Government to introduce economies in the administration. In fact, I support it. Nor am I challenging the Government's right to introduce pay cuts, but I do want to protest against the manner in which they have gone about their business. To say the least, Sir, it is most undemocratic.

    At this point, the Member for Cairnhill took off his glasses and polished it.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Excuse me, Sir, for polishing my glasses. I want to have a better view of hon. Members on the other side of the House.

    Mr Speaker: Order. That action and that phrase may well be said to be intimidating, although I am sure there are robust people on the Government Benches. But I must remind the hon. Member for Cairnhill that he is addressing the Chair, and if he has polished his glasses to look at the Speaker, then, of course, he is completely in order.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, my view of your honourable self has not been clouded, but my view of the Members on the other side has been clouded by the change in colour of some of its Members. Ah! now I have got them in the proper perspective.

    The Hon. the Minister for Labour and Law, the Hon. the Minister for Finance, who is not here at the moment and his seat is therefore unoccupied, and the Hon. the Deputy Speaker, who is I believe still the Secretary-General of the Trades Union Congress, and of course, the Hon. the Prime Minister - these men, Sir, these honourable men first won their way into the political field through championing the Government servants. These champions, I am sorry, I mean these ex-champions, brought into being the Council of Joint Action. They fought hard and they fought bitterly against the then Government and won their way into the hearts of trade unionists in Singapore. They even won their way into my heart! Those were indeed the days, Sir! The Council of Joint Action was a Council

Column: 166

of Joint Action, and woe to the Government if it had dared to take the line that the glorious P.A.P. Government is now taking. Those were indeed the days. Today, Sir, we see a complete change, a complete change. The Government servants formed a Council of Joint Action to protect their interests against dictatorial employers, and what did one of the fathers, not here at the moment, of the original Council of Joint Action say? The P.A.P. Government does not recognise the Council of Joint Action. Do I hear applause? No. No applause.

    Mr Speaker: That would be out of order, of course.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Therefore, the verdict is indeed a shameful verdict.

    To introduce pay cuts arbitrarily without even giving one month's notice to monthly-rated employees is. I maintain, contrary to law. The Government, as employers, cannot change-

    The Prime Minister: On a point of information, Sir.

    Mr Speaker: If the hon. Member will give way.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: I am still speaking, Sir. The Hon. the Prime Minister will have a right to speak in due course, and I do not think the Hon. the Prime Minister would want to be further informed as he is already so well informed.

    The Government, Sir, as employers, cannot change the terms of contract of its employees without due notice. They cannot change a monthly contract without giving one month's due notice.

    The Prime Minister: Is that what you got your LL.D. for?

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Will the Hon. the Minister for Labour and Law look into this matter? I remember when I was the Minister for Labour and Welfare, it had been brought to my attention, many a time, by P.A.P. trade union leaders that such and such employers were most undemocratic, most dictatorial, because they had not given the employees due notice. Times have changed. Times indeed have changed.

Column: 167



    Sir, the Staff side claimed that there had been no negotiations on these pay cuts. The Government refuted this. From Press reports and from personal experience of trade union negotiations, I maintain that there had been no negotiations in the proper sense. Only two meetings were held, and these on successive days. Surely, Sir, in a matter of this grave nature, the representatives of the Staff side would have had to consult their trade unions before they could speak with authority. And the law requires that there should be proper notice being given for such meetings of trade unions to be held. The Minister for Finance claims that any delay in reaching agreement would be to the disadvantage of the Government. Surely, with his experience of trade union negotiations, what was required at the initial meetings was to agree on an operative date and this, I understand, the Staff side was prepared to do. After the operative date had been agreed upon, any delay through negotiations in reaching agreement on the quantum would have had no material effect. Oh, no! This is not to be. The Government means business. The Staff side has to take it because their champions, or rather their ex-champions, say so! The Government cannot be pressured into retreating. These are their words, Sir, their own words, "The Government cannot be pressured into retreating". But who is exercising pressure on whom in this case? I ask this House - who is exercising pressure on whom?

    The previous Government, Sir, the much-maligned Lim Yew Hock Government, had an agreement with the Staff side that in cases where no agreement could be reached through negotiations, the matter could go to arbitration at the request of either side. I am surprised that the Staff side did not try to get out of this pressure by demanding - oh, no, they should not demand - by requesting that the matter should go to arbitration. The Government, Sir, in the words of the Minister for Finance, cannot be pressured, and so even if the Staff side had requested arbitration, the Government

Column: 168

might have said that it had scrapped the agreement reached between the Staff side and the previous Government. Perhaps I am doing the P.A.P. an injustice. Perhaps they will agree to refer the matter to arbitration, and I would like their answer to this. I cannot help but keep on recalling to my mind the words of the Minister for Finance - that the Government cannot be pressured into retreating. Judging from his speech during the debate on the City Council (Suspension and Transfer of Functions) Bill two days ago, the Minister for Finance is doubtless less concerned with the observance of the democratic institution of arbitration tribunals. He is more concerned with the substance, and the substance in this case is the Government's decision to introduce pay cuts. The Government could not care less about the method of achieving this substance. To them the method adopted by them is democratic, and if the poor Opposition have the temerity to say that such a method is undemocratic and dictatorial, they would stand up and remind us, maybe with grins spreading all over their faces: "We have 43 members, and what about you - just 8." That is the substance of democracy. So, Sir, I do not think they would worry about arbitration at all. So obviously the answer to my suggestion of referring the matter to arbitration is going to be no.

    How then are they going to reconcile this stand if they were to say "No" with their policy on industrial relations? I quote from the Hansard, Volume 11 No. 1, column 9:

    "...the channel for the solution of industrial disputes is direct negotiations between employer and Union, then conciliation through the Ministry of Labour and Law, and only finally the Court of Labour."

Sir, this Court of Labour is to have powers to enforce its awards. On the one hand, they say what they mean - column 9, and, on the other hand, in the treatment of their own employees, they do not mean what they say. They are indeed an honest Government! God help us.

    Mr Speaker: Order. There is, of course, a direct implication that the Government is a dishonest Government. Therefore that expression must be withdrawn.

Column: 169



    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Sir, I will, therefore, not call on God at all. I withdraw.

    Mr Speaker: Am I right in saying that I heard the hon. Member saying that "the Government is indeed an honest Government"? There is a direct implication, of course, that the Government is dishonest, and therefore it is parliamentarily wrong.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: I am sorry, Sir, that I cannot even say that they are an honest Government, because of the form in which I used it.

    Mr Speaker: An apology is not enough. I want a withdrawal of that statement which implies that the Government is dishonest, and the hon. Member knows that an implication of that nature is highly unparliamentary.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: I beg to withdraw, Sir, and tender due apologies. Thank you.

    If the previous Government had taken this arbitrary and dictatorial stand, not only would the Council of Joint Action be reformed by their trusted champions (now ex-champions) but they would be most vociferous in their clamour for justice. Not only would this happen, Sir, but outside P.A.P. unions would be organising protest meetings pledging their full support to their brothers in distress to fight to the bitter end. How dare the Lim Yew Hock Government strike a death blow at the accepted practice of trade unions negotiations, and so on and so forth. But what do we see today? The very life of the trade union movement is at stake. It is not the question of pay cuts at all. It is the negation of the right of trade unions to proper negotiations. What do we see today? All quiet on the trade union front! Even the Trades Union Congress, whose Secretary-General is the Hon, the Deputy Speaker, is deadly silent.     If I have hurt the feelings of the Hon. the Prime Minister, I wish to apologise. I would like to explain that, in my opinion, we are today only in a state of self-government.
